questions.text: Disease caused by this vector ?
questions.solution:
Dengue is transmitted primarily by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

  1. Distinctive Black and White Pattern: Aedes mosquitoes have white markings on their legs and a lyre-shaped pattern of white scales on the upper surface of their thorax.
  2. Daytime Biters: Aedes mosquitoes are most active during the day, especially early morning and late afternoon.
  3. Eggs Laid in Dry Areas: They lay eggs in containers or areas that can later hold water, but the eggs can survive for long periods without water.
  4. Vector for Diseases: They are known carriers of diseases like dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  5. Breeding in Clean Water: Aedes mosquitoes breed in clean, stagnant water found in containers, tires, and pots.
  6. Short Flight Range: They typically have a limited flight range of 50-100 meters from their breeding sites.

Option (a): Malaria is caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium, and it is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes.


Option (b): The primary vectors for JEV are mosquitoes of the genus Culex. Specifically, Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the main vector in many areas.


Option (d): Kala Azar is transmitted through the bite of infected female sandflies, particularly those of the genus Phlebotomus


KEY TAKEAWAYS- Dengue is transmitted primarily by mosquitoes of the genus Aedes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-15, Page number:835-840.

questions.text: The most common cause of this malformation is the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
In pregnant women, folic acid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the developing fetus, such as spina bifida and anencephaly.

Option (a): Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can lead beriberi. Beriberi is a condition that affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

Option (b): Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency leads to a condition known as pellagra.


Option (d): Cyanocobalamin deficiency, which is a form of vitamin B12 deficiency, can lead to Megaloblastic Anemia

KEY TAKEWAYS- In pregnant women, folic acid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the developing fetus, such as spina bifida and anencephaly.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-09, Page number: 610-615.

questions.text: What is the composition of this medicine?
questions.solution:
• Antara is an injectable contraceptive that contains the hormone Medroxyprogesterone acetate (a form of progesterone). It does not contain estrogen.
  • Antara is an injectable contraceptive used in family planning programs, particularly in India. It contains Medroxyprogesterone acetate, a synthetic form of the hormone progesterone.
  • This contraceptive is administered via intramuscular injection and provides long-term contraception, typically effective for three months per injection.

Key Points about Antara:


KEY TAKEAWAYS- Antara is an injectable contraceptive that contains the hormone Medroxyprogesterone acetate (a form of progesterone). It does not contain estrogen.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-08, Page number: 566-570.

questions.text: All diseases are included in this programme except?
questions.solution:
Yellow fever is not included in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) of India.

The NVBDCP focuses on the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Malaria (option A)
  • Filariasis (option B)
  • Dengue
  • Chikungunya
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Kala-azar (Leishmaniasis) (option D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Yellow fever, although a vector-borne disease, is not a major public health concern in India and is not covered under the NVBDCP.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-11, Page number: 376-381.

questions.text: HIV positive person with CD 4 count of <50/cu mm of blood. Presented with lesion shown in image. Most likely diagnosisis?
questions.solution:
CMV Retinitis (Cytomegalovirus Retinitis) is an opportunistic eye infection primarily seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS or organ transplants.

  1. Causative Agent: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a herpesvirus, is the causative agent of this retinal infection.
  2. Risk Factors:
    • Immunosuppression, particularly in patients with CD4 counts below 50 cells/μL in HIV/AIDS.
    • Organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy.
    • Long-term corticosteroid or chemotherapy use.
  3. Symptoms:
    • Blurred vision or decreased visual acuity.
    • Floaters or flashes of light.
    • Loss of peripheral vision (can progress to blindness if untreated).
    • Often asymptomatic in early stages.
  4. Fundoscopic Findings:
    • "Pizza pie" or "cheese and ketchup" appearance due to hemorrhagic retinal necrosis.
    • White, granular retinal infiltrates with hemorrhages.
    • Retinal atrophy in chronic cases.

Here is a tabular representation of opportunistic infections associated with a CD4 count of <50 cells/mm³ in an HIV-positive person:


KEY TAKEAWAYS- CMV Retinitis (Cytomegalovirus Retinitis) is an opportunistic eye infection primarily seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS or organ transplants.

Reference: National Guideline for HIV Care & Treatment, MOHFW, GOI, section number.-3, Page Number -78-83. https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_HIV_Care_and_Treatment_2021.pdf

choices.text: Eradication strategy- catch up, keep up, follow up
Vaccine started at 9 months of age
Killed vaccine given by intramuscular route

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to clinic by her mother saying that child is having fever, running nose, and difficulty in swallowing. on examination, you noticed a lesion given in the image. All are true for given condition except?
questions.solution:
Based on the presentation of a 3-year-old child with fever, runny nose, difficulty swallowing, and Koplik's spots, which indicate measles

  1. Viral disease which is vaccine preventable - True. Measles is a viral disease and is preventable with the measles vaccine.
  2. Eradication strategy - catch up, keep up, follow up - True. This strategy is used in vaccination programs to ensure that children receive their vaccines on time and address missed doses.
  3. Vaccine started at 9 months of age - Partially True. The routine MMR vaccine is typically given at 12-15 months of age, though it can be administered as early as 6-9 months in outbreak situations or high-risk areas.
  4. Killed vaccine given by intramuscular route - False. The MMR vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, not a killed vaccine, and it is given by the subcutaneous route, not intramuscularly.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Child with fever, runny nose, difficulty swallowing, and Koplik's spots, indicate measles.

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017, MOHFW, GOI, unit number.-04, Page Number -19-26.

questions.text: Chemical used to kill the larva is ?
questions.solution:
The chemical used to kill the larvae of Anopheles mosquitoes is: a. Paris green

  • Paris green (copper(II) acetoarsenite) is an insecticide specifically used for larvicidal action against Anopheles mosquito larvae, which are responsible for the transmission of malaria.
  • DDT is primarily used as an adulticide, targeting adult mosquitoes.
  • Abate (Temephos) is another larvicide used for controlling mosquito larvae, but it is not as commonly associated with Anopheles specifically as Paris green.
  • Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide used against adult mosquitoes and other pests but is not primarily used for larval control of Anopheles.

Therefore, Paris green is the most appropriate answer.


KEY TAKEAWAYS- Paris green (copper(II) acetoarsenite) is an insecticide specifically used for larvicidal action against Anopheles mosquito larvae, which are responsible for the transmission of malaria

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-11, Page number:396-400.

questions.text: All of the following comes under the image given below except?
questions.solution:
UNICEF (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) is a global agency under the United Nations that focuses on advocating for the rights and well-being of children around the world.

Overview

  • Founded: 1946
  • Headquarters: New York, USA
  • Mission: To promote and protect the rights of every child, especially the most disadvantaged, through advocacy, programs, and partnerships.

UNICEF operates in over 190 countries and territories, working with local communities, governments, and other partners to improve the lives of children. It is known for its work in immunization, education, emergency relief, and child protection, significantly contributing to global child health and well-being.

Notable Campaigns

  • UNICEF's Polio Eradication Campaign: A global initiative to eradicate polio.
  • Back to School Campaigns: Ensuring that children affected by emergencies return to school as quickly as possible.
  • END violence: A campaign to raise awareness and take action against violence against children.

Key Activities of UNICEF


KEY TAKEAWAYS- UNICEF (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) is a global agency under the United Nations that focuses on advocating for the rights and well-being of children around the world.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-25, Page number: 1020-1025.

questions.text: What is the Composition of meal under this activity?
questions.solution:
The composition of a meal under the Mid Day Meal (MDM) program typically includes: 1/2 protein; 1/3 calorie

The Mid Day Meal program aims to provide a balanced diet with an emphasis on protein and calorie content to ensure children receive adequate nutrition for growth and development.

Here's key features of the Mid Day Meal (MDM) program:


KEY TAKEAWAYS- The composition of a meal under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) program typically includes: 1/2 protein; 1/3 calorie

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-18, Page number: 503-506.

questions.text: Main worker of this programme is?
questions.solution:
The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), launched in 2005, aimed to enhance healthcare delivery in rural India. Here are some key features:

  1. Objective: NRHM focused on providing accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to rural populations, with a special emphasis on maternal and child health, family planning, and prevention and management of communicable and non-communicable diseases.
  2. Service Delivery: The mission aimed to strengthen the primary healthcare infrastructure by upgrading Sub-Centers, Primary Health Centers (PHCs), and Community Health Centers (CHCs), as well as supporting district hospitals.
  3. Human Resources: NRHM emphasized the training and capacity building of healthcare workers, including the recruitment of Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs), Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs), and other health personnel.
  4. Community Participation: A core feature was involving local communities in health planning and decision-making through Village Health and Sanitation Committees (VHSCs) and other local bodies.
  5. Funding: The mission's funding was shared between central and state governments, supporting both infrastructure development and the provision of healthcare services.
  6. Integration with Other Programs: NRHM worked in conjunction with other programs like Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) and the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (NREGS) to improve health infrastructure and services.
  7. Health Promotion: The mission promoted health education and awareness campaigns, focusing on preventive and promotive health measures to improve community health outcomes.
  8. Infrastructure Improvement: NRHM supported the construction and renovation of health facilities and provided essential medical equipment and supplies.
  9. Monitoring and Evaluation: Regular monitoring and evaluation were integral to NRHM, with mechanisms in place for continuous improvement based on feedback and health service outcomes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Main worker of this programme is ASHA.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-06, Page number: 117-120.

questions.text: Disease caused by toxin of seeds of this plant is ?
questions.solution:
Epidemic Dropsy is a form of edema (swelling) that occurs due to the consumption of adulterated mustard oil.

The condition is primarily caused by contamination of mustard oil with Argemone oil, which is extracted from the seeds of the Argemone mexicana plant. This adulteration leads to a toxic reaction in the body, resulting in the clinical features associated with epidemic dropsy.

Key Features of Epidemic Dropsy:

  1. Edema:
    • The hallmark of epidemic dropsy is bilateral pitting edema, especially in the lower limbs. This swelling is due to fluid accumulation in the tissues.
  2. Gastrointestinal Symptoms:
    • Patients may experience nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which are common in the early stages of the disease.
  3. Cardiovascular Issues:
    • The condition can lead to serious cardiac symptoms, including palpitations, breathlessness, and in severe cases, congestive heart failure.
  4. Skin Eruptions:
    • Skin changes like erythema (redness), eruptions, and a feeling of warmth in the affected areas are also observed.
  5. Respiratory Symptoms:
    • Breathlessness and cough may develop, often related to fluid overload and heart failure.
  6. Complications:
    • If untreated, epidemic dropsy can lead to complications such as heart failure, renal failure, glaucoma, and even death.
  7. Treatment:
    • Immediate discontinuation of the contaminated oil is essential.
    • Treatment involves managing symptoms with diuretics for edema, cardiac support, and other supportive measures as needed.
  8. Prevention:
    • Prevention focuses on ensuring the purity of mustard oil, public awareness campaigns, and stringent regulation and monitoring of edible oils to prevent contamination.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Epidemic Dropsy is a form of edema (swelling) that occurs due to the consumption of adulterated mustard oil.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-11,Page no.: 750-756.

choices.text: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels heal
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.text: True about given image is ?
questions.solution:
Horrock's Apparatus:

Purpose: Horrock's Apparatus is used primarily for preparing and standardizing chlorine solutions for the disinfection of drinking water. This apparatus ensures that the correct concentration of chlorine is used to effectively disinfect water, making it safe for consumption.

The apparatus works by estimating the chlorine demand of water. The starch iodide indicator changes color to blue during the process. The amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 liters of water is (nx2) grams, where n is the first cup that changes color.


KEY TAKEAWAYS-The Horrock's Apparatus is a simple and traditional tool used to estimate the chlorine demand of water for disinfection purposes. It is primarily used in field settings, especially in public health and water treatment scenarios.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-15,Page no.:856-860.

choices.text: Vitamin B complex and vitamin K
Safflower oil and vitamin B complex

questions.text: A patient presented with the following Skin finding. You would advise supplementation with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

Phrynoderma is a skin condition commonly associated with deficiency of nutrients such as essential fatty acids, vitamin A, vitamin E, and B-complex vitamins may also contribute. The condition is characterized by the development of rough, dry, and bumpy skin, particularly on the extensor surfaces like the elbows, knees, and buttocks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-11,Page no.:750-756.

choices.text: Implemented by Ministry of Women & Child Development
It provides a cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization across public and private empanelled hospitals in India
NITI Aayog has played a critical role in shaping the above health scheme

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about the health scheme represented by given logo?
questions.solution:
POSHAN Abhiyaan was launched by the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi on the occasion of the International Women's Day on 8th March, 2018 from Jhunjhunu in Rajasthan.

POSHAN Abhiyaan is the Government of India's flagship programme to improve nutritional outcomes for children, adolescents, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

POSHAN (Prime Minister's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment) Abhiyaan is not a programme but a Jan Andolan, and Bhagidaari, meaning "People's Movement." This programme incorporates inclusive participation of public representatives of local bodies, government departments of the state, social organizations and the public and private sector at large.


KEY TAKEAWAYS-POSHAN Abhiyaan is the Government of India's flagship programme to improve nutritional outcomes for children, adolescents, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore,chapter-18,Page no.:510-516.

choices.text: Malnutrition can be detected even before signs and symptoms appear
It provides an objective basis for policy making on child healthcare
It can be used to teach the importance of adequate feeding
It can be used to indicate proof of government aid

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the following tool :
questions.solution:
The given image shows a growth chart. It is not used as proof of government aid.

  • Growth charts are essential tools used by healthcare providers to monitor the growth and development of children.
  • They plot a child's growth measurements, such as weight, height/length, and head circumference, against a reference population to assess whether the child is growing at a healthy rate.
  • By comparing a child's measurements with standardized percentiles or Z-scores, growth charts help identify potential growth concerns like undernutrition, stunting, or obesity.
  • Regular tracking on growth charts allows for early detection of any deviations from expected growth patterns, enabling timely interventions and ensuring that children are on a healthy developmental path.
  • Separate growth charts are used for different age groups and genders to account for natural differences in growth patterns.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Growth charts are essential tools used by healthcare providers to monitor the growth and development of children

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-11,Page no.:756-760.
